educational_objective: Identify left ventricular hypertrophy on ECG.
question_text: A 44-year-old man with a newly diagnosed ischemic stroke is evaluated in the emergency department.ECG is shown.
question_stem: Which of the following abnormalities is seen on this patient's ECG?
critique: This ECG demonstrates features of left ventricular hypertrophy (Option B), including both Sokolow-Lyon ECG criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy:Sum of the deepest S wave in lead V1 and the tallest R wave in lead V5 or V6 is 35 mm or greater, orR wave in lead aVL is 11 mm or greater.Alternatively, the Cornell criteria specify that left ventricular hypertrophy is present if the S wave in lead V3 plus R wave in aVL sums to greater than 20 mm for women or greater than 28 mm for men.Secondary STâ€“T-wave abnormalities (asymmetric ST-segment depression and T-wave inversion) are another indicator of left ventricular hypertrophy and are seen in leads I, aVL, and V4 through V6 in this tracing. The QRS duration is normal in this tracing, precluding the diagnosis of a bundle branch block.

figures.title: ECG Showing Left Ventricular Hypertrophy
